title: Implement Unix socket server with JSON-RPC protocol
description:
# Description

Implement the Unix socket server and JSON-RPC protocol for daemon communication. This enables CLI commands to control the running daemon.

# Relevant Files

- internal/daemon/server.go (new file)
- internal/daemon/protocol.go (new file)
- internal/daemon/handlers.go (new file)
- docs/components/daemon.md:157-273 (server specification)

# Implementation

1. Create internal/daemon/protocol.go:
   - Request struct with Method and ID fields
   - Response struct with Result, Error, and ID fields
   - StatusResponse struct with Status, CurrentBead, Uptime, StartTime, Stats
   - StatusStats struct matching workqueue.QueueStats

2. Create internal/daemon/server.go:
   - serve(ctx) - accept loop with graceful shutdown
   - handleConnection(ctx, conn) - read request, dispatch, write response
   - Use json.Decoder/Encoder with io.LimitedReader (1MB max)
   - Set 30s read deadline per connection
   - Set socket permissions to 0600

3. Create internal/daemon/handlers.go:
   - handleRequest(ctx, req) - dispatch to method handlers
   - handleStatus() - return StatusResponse from controller
   - handlePause() - call controller.Pause()
   - handleResume() - call controller.Resume()
   - handleStop(force bool) - call controller.Stop(), schedule daemon shutdown

4. Add Start(ctx) and Stop() methods to Daemon struct

# Acceptance Criteria

- Socket accepts connections and handles JSON-RPC requests
- All four methods work: status, pause, resume, stop
- Stop with force param triggers immediate shutdown
- Connection timeout prevents hung clients
- Message size limit prevents DoS
- Socket permissions are 0600

# Verification

- [ ] `mise run lint` passes
- [ ] `mise run test` passes
- [ ] Manual test: start daemon, send status request via nc or socat

title: Fix cost tracking double-count bug
description:
# Description
Fix the cost/turns double-counting issue in StateSink and ensure cost data flows correctly from parser to TUI.

## Problem
1. StateSink adds cost for BOTH SessionEndEvent AND IterationEndEvent (double-count)
2. Controller.runSession() returns empty SessionResult{} - cost is always zero in IterationEndEvent
3. TUI shows $0.00 because it reads from IterationEndEvent

## Solution

### Part 1: Parser captures session result
- Add `result atomic.Value` field to Parser struct
- In handleResultEvent(), store event in atomic.Value before emitting
- Add Result() method that returns captured *SessionEndEvent
- Use atomic.Value for thread-safe access (parser runs in goroutine)

### Part 2: Controller retrieves result
- After parser.Parse() completes, call parser.Result()
- Populate SessionResult with NumTurns, TotalCostUSD from parser result
- Handle nil result gracefully (log warning, return zero values)

### Part 3: Fix double-count in StateSink
- Add `countedSessions map[string]bool` to StateSink
- In SessionEndEvent handler: only add cost if session not already counted
- In IterationEndEvent handler: mark session as counted after adding cost
- IterationEndEvent is authoritative source for totals

## Files to modify
- internal/session/parser.go - Add result capture and Result() method
- internal/controller/controller.go - Retrieve parser result in runSession()
- internal/events/statesink.go - Add session deduplication

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] TUI displays actual cost from Claude session (not $0.00)
- [ ] State file totals match TUI display
- [ ] No double-counting when both events fire
- [ ] Tests verify cost flow end-to-end

## Verification
- [ ] `mise run lint` passes
- [ ] `mise run test` passes
- [ ] Manual: Run atari, process a bead, verify cost > $0 in TUI
close_reason: Fixed cost tracking double-count bug. Parser now captures SessionEndEvent via Result() method for controller retrieval. StateSink uses countedSessions map to prevent double-counting when both events fire. Tests verify cost flow end-to-end. Lint and tests pass.

   - eventMsg: Wrapped events.Event from channel

   - tickMsg: Periodic tick for stats sync

   - Block on channel receive

   - r: Call onResume callback, set status to resuming

   - Set tooSmall flag if below minimum

title: Implement events package router
description:
# Description

Create the channel-based pub/sub event router that allows components to emit events and sinks to subscribe to them.

## Scope

Create `internal/events/router.go` with:

1. **Router struct**:
   ```go
   type Router struct {
       subscribers []subscriberEntry
       bufferSize  int
       mu          sync.RWMutex
       closed      bool
   }
   
   type subscriberEntry struct {
       ch       chan Event
       blocking bool
   }
   ```

2. **Core methods**:
   - `NewRouter(bufferSize int) *Router` - Constructor with default buffer size
   - `Emit(event Event)` - Publish event to all subscribers
   - `Subscribe() <-chan Event` - Get buffered event channel
   - `SubscribeBuffered(size int) <-chan Event` - Custom buffer size
   - `Unsubscribe(ch <-chan Event)` - Remove subscription
   - `Close()` - Close all subscriber channels

3. **Emit behavior**:
   - Non-blocking send to buffered subscribers (drop on full)
   - Log warning when events are dropped (use slog)

4. **Thread safety**:
   - RWMutex protects subscriber list
   - Emit uses read lock, Subscribe/Unsubscribe use write lock

## Design Decisions

- Default buffer size: 100 events
- Drop policy: non-blocking send, log warning on drop
- State sink should use SubscribeBuffered(1000) to reduce drops
- Close() closes all channels, subsequent Emit() is no-op

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Single subscriber receives all emitted events
- [ ] Multiple subscribers each receive all events
- [ ] Unsubscribe removes subscriber correctly
- [ ] Close() closes all channels
- [ ] Full buffer results in drop + warning log
- [ ] Thread-safe under concurrent access

- internal/tui/tui.go: Integration with Run() method
- golang.org/x/term: TTY detection dependency

   - isTerminal(): Check both stdout AND stdin are TTY
   - terminalSize(): Get current terminal dimensions
   - terminalTooSmall(): Check if below 60x15 minimum
2. Implement runSimple() method:
   - Read events from channel in loop
   - Format each event using Format() function
   - Print to stdout with timestamp prefix
   - Exit when channel closes
   - Handle ctrl+c for early exit
3. Update tui.go Run() method:
   - Check isTerminal() at startup
   - If not terminal: call runSimple() directly
   - If terminal too small: call runSimple() directly
   - Otherwise: run full bubbletea TUI
4. Note: Dynamic switching between full/minimal modes happens within Tea (not runSimple)
   - runSimple is startup-only fallback
   - Within Tea, resize below minimum shows tooSmall message

# Description
Add duration tracking to the TUI to show both current bead elapsed time and total accumulated duration across all iterations. Display in human-friendly format.

# Requirements
- Track current bead elapsed time (live, updates on tick)
- Track total accumulated duration across all iterations
- Display format: "<60s" for under a minute, "Xm" for minutes, "Xh Ym" for hours
- Update on every 2s tick (no minute gating needed)
- Nil-safe handling for dropped events

# Implementation

## model.go
- Add StartTime (time.Time) to beadInfo struct
- Add to modelStats: TotalDurationMs (int64), CurrentDurationMs (int64)

## update.go handleEvent
- IterationStartEvent: capture event.Timestamp() to beadInfo.StartTime
- IterationEndEvent: accumulate e.DurationMs to TotalDurationMs, clear CurrentDurationMs

## update.go handleTick
- Always run stats sync (no gating)
- If currentBead != nil and StartTime is set: CurrentDurationMs = time.Since(StartTime)

## view.go renderHeader
- Line 2: append current elapsed in brackets after bead title: "bead: bd-123 - Title [5m]"
- Line 3: add total duration to stats line: "turns: 42  total: 1h 23m  completed: 4..."

## format.go
- Add formatDurationHuman(ms int64) string
- Returns "<60s", "Xm", "Xh", "Xh Ym"
- Handle negative/zero gracefully

## styles.go
- Add Duration style (color 220, same as Cost)

# Edge Cases
- Nil pointer safety: check iterationStartTime before use
- Event drops: log warning if IterationEndEvent without Start, use event DurationMs
- State loss on restart: accept (same as cost/turns behavior)
- Fallback mode: duration shows in IterationEndEvent format only (no live elapsed)

# Testing
- update_test.go: state transitions for duration fields
- format_test.go: formatDurationHuman boundary cases
- view_test.go: header rendering includes duration

# Overview
Implement interactive Q&A pane in the TUI for real-time understanding of drain activity and intervention guidance. Users can ask questions about what the drain is doing and get context-aware responses from Claude.

# Scope
- ObserverConfig for user customization
- Session broker for Claude process coordination (single-session rule)

- Observer query execution with --resume support

- Observer pane UI component with textarea input
- Horizontal/vertical split layout
- CLI flags for observer configuration
- End-to-end tests and documentation

- Default layout: Horizontal (events left, observer right)
